title: enhancement: implement instantiation methods for entity types
body:
Closes #951 and #963.

### Description
This PR adds a `::new()` method to entity types that automatically calculates an ID for the user so that they do not have to come up with their own way to create one. It also adds a `::get_or_create()` method that will load a record from the DB if present or create the struct as described above.

### Testing steps

The `hello-world` example has been changed to illustrate the new instantiation methods.
1. Ensure the test DB is cleared and that the `hello-world` WASM module has been freshly built.
2. `cargo run -p hello-world-node`
3. `cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --manifest examples/hello-world/hello-indexer/hello_indexer.manifest.yaml --verbose`
4. `cargo run -p hello-world-data`
5. Check the output of the indexer; you should see that the original and `::new()` methods insert data into the DB, and that `::get_or_create()` loads a record from the database.

### Changelog

- Add a number of `HashSet`s for checking whether a field type implements the requisite traits
- Add a helper function for creating the necessary method implementations

title: enhancement: implement union types

labels.name: fuel-explorer
labels.description: This PR is directly related to the block explorer

body:
- [ ] Please add proper labels
- [ ] If there is an issue associated with this PR, please link the issue (right-hand sidebar)
- [ ] If there is not an issue associated with this PR, add this PR to the "Fuel Indexer" project (right-hand sidebar)

### Description

- This PR adds support for `union` types in GraphQL
- `union` types are created using a the set of fields between all the union's members
- Some notes:
  - Tables _will_ be created from union types (even if the contents of the union are themselves unindexable)
- `union` types work very similarly to `object` types
  - The main difference is, when using an `object`, the fields are directly on the object
  - However, when using a `union`, you have to look up the members of the union in order to find the set of fields shared between all members of the union
- `union` fields are _all_ optional, except the `ID` field.
- Tests were added
- I will integrate this new functionality into the explorer after this PR is merged
- [More detail on why this approach](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/issues/988#issuecomment-1584518964)

### Testing steps

- [ ] Tests were added so CI should pass
- [ ] Run the service on beta-3 with the test indexer and inspect your tables

```bash
cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --manifest  packages/fuel-indexer-tests/components/indices/fuel-indexer-test/fuel_indexer_test.yaml --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --verbos
```

### Changelog

Please add a neat Changelog info here according to our [Contributor's Guide](./CONTRIBUTING.md).

title: fix: various auth updates
body:
- [ ] Please add proper labels
- [ ] If there is an issue associated with this PR, please link the issue (right-hand sidebar)
- [ ] If there is not an issue associated with this PR, add this PR to the "Fuel Indexer" project (right-hand sidebar)

### Description

- Whilst deploying an indexer to the playground I noticed authentication was buggy
- This PR fixes 3 issues:
  - Removes auth from `register_indexer_assets`
  - Fixes sqlx type issue in `queries::indexer_owned_by`
  - Uses the public key in `index_registry` (not the issuer)
- This was previously unnoticed cause I never run the indexer locally with auth (will change that going forward)
- Obviously an integration test would help here. Happy for anyone to open that PR ;) 

### Testing steps

- [ ] You will need two accounts in your `forc-wallet` (account index `0` and account index `1`)
- [ ] Start the service with auth enabled on beta3
```bash
cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --auth-enabled --auth-strategy jwt --jwt-secret abcdefg --jwt-issuer FuelLabs
```
- [ ] Authenticate using your first account `forc index auth`
- [ ] Use this token to deploy an indexer `forc index deploy --auth $TOKEN1`
  - On master this fails due to the SQLx type issue _and_ the unnecessary authentication check
- [ ] Authenticate using your second account `forc index auth`
- [ ] Use this token to try to remove the indexer your just deployed `forc index remove --auth $TOKEN2`
  - This will fail as `Unauthorized`
 

### Changelog

- fix: various auth updates

title: fuel-indexer run --replace-indexer
body:
- [ ] Please add proper labels
- [ ] If there is an issue associated with this PR, please link the issue (right-hand sidebar)
- [ ] If there is not an issue associated with this PR, add this PR to the "Fuel Indexer" project (right-hand sidebar)

### Description

Add `--replace-indexer` flag which changes how `forc index deploy` works: deployed indexer completely replaces the existing indexer(s) under the same UID. All previous indexer assets, graphql entries, and indexer tables are removed.

### Testing steps

I have a simple contract/script/indexer which may be helpful: https://github.com/lostman/fuel-counter

1. Run `cargo run --features fuel-core-lib -p fuel-indexer -- run --local-fuel-node --replace-indexer`
2. `git clone https://github.com/lostman/fuel-counter`
3. Create an indexer with colliding UID `examples.counter_indexer` that we will replace later:
```
mkdir dummy && cd dummy && forc index new --namespace examples counter_indexer && cd counter_indexer && forc deploy
```
4 Deploy the `counter` contract, an indexer, and run a script to trigger an event: `cd fuel-counter && make`
5. Confirm that the dummy indexer was replaced and that an event was indexed:
```
postgres=> select * from examples_counter_indexer.increntity;
         id          | value |                                 object
---------------------+-------+------------------------------------------------------------------------
 7003491485461406310 |   123 | \x02000000000000000d0000000166626662666631611e000000017b00000000000000
 ```

### Changelog

* Add `--replace-indexer` flag
* Change `remove_indexer` to remove the indexer, grapgl related entries, and schema tables.
* Remove `forc index revert` and all mentions from the docs.

labels.name: fuel-explorer

body:
- [ ] Please add proper labels
- [ ] If there is an issue associated with this PR, please link the issue (right-hand sidebar)
- [ ] If there is not an issue associated with this PR, add this PR to the "Fuel Indexer" project (right-hand sidebar)

### Description

- Reorganizes type imports hopefully one last time
- Common types (e.g., `BlockData`) and field traits (e.g., `ReceiptsRoot`) are exported directly in the plugins `types`
  - We don't allow schema objects to have these ☝🏽 names
  - _Everything_ copied from `fuel_client_schema` is now in the `fuel_indexer_types::fuels` module
    - When we refactor/replace these types, we only have to update one file
    - Namespacing these types under `fuel::` allows users to use these same common names in their GraphQL schema

### Testing steps

title: enhancement: support list types in schema macro
body:
_Note: This is being merged into a feature branch._

### Description
Allows for list types to be properly decoded in the schema macro. Note that this does not implement querying for list types, which will come at a later time.

### Testing steps
CI should pass as there should be no outward changes just yet. Proper tests will be added to the feature branch at a later time.

#### Manual Testing
Using the `hello-indexer` example, ensure that the WASM module builds with no errors for the four possible cases:

1. Non-nullable list of non-nullable elements (`Vec<FtColumn>`):
- Add the following to the `Salutation` entity in the schema: `words: [Charfield!]!`
- Add the following line to the `Salutation` struct in the handler: `words: vec!["Hello".to_string()]`
- Ensure that `cargo build` completes successfully.

2. Non-nullable list of nullable elements (`Vec<Option<FtColumn>>`):
- Add the following to the `Salutation` entity in the schema: `words: [Charfield]!`
- Add the following line to the `Salutation` struct in the handler: `words: vec![Some("Hello".to_string())]`
- Ensure that `cargo build` completes successfully.

3. Nullable list of non-nullable elements (`Option<Vec<FtColumn>>`):
- Add the following to the `Salutation` entity in the schema: `words: [Charfield!]`
- Add the following line to the `Salutation` struct in the handler: `words: Some(vec!["Hello".to_string()])`
- Ensure that `cargo build` completes successfully.

4. Nullable list of nullable elements (`Option<Vec<Option<FtColumn>>>`):
- Add the following to the `Salutation` entity in the schema: `words: [Charfield]`
- Add the following line to the `Salutation` struct in the handler: `words: Some(vec![Some("Hello".to_string())])`
- Ensure that `cargo build` completes successfully.

### Changelog

- [Add basic query fragment for list](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/commit/7c77eec25eb6c29d10cefbfcf457e054b78fd72c)
- [Add list type processing to schema macro](https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/commit/9fbb08eae3040f2bc7ca5ff21398935a0a857409)

body:
- [ ] Please add proper labels
- [ ] If there is an issue associated with this PR, please link the issue (right-hand sidebar)
- [ ] If there is not an issue associated with this PR, add this PR to the "Fuel Indexer" project (right-hand sidebar)

### Description

- PR adds support for a `@norelation` directive
  - Applying this directive to any field on an object renders the entire object as `NoRelation`, which means the object is stored as `Json`
    - I chose `Json` over `Blob` because I think it might be easier to extract the item into an object
      - This will definitely require a second pass later
- PR also moves some code around (moves `serialize` and `deserialize` from fuel-indexer-schema to fuel-indexer-lib)
- 

### Testing steps

- [ ] Test was added so CI should pass
- [ ] Build assets `bash scripts/utils/build_test_wasm_module.bash`
- [ ] Start a local fuel node `cargo run -p fuel-node --bin fuel-node`
- [ ] Start the web API `cargo run -p web-api --bin web-api`
- [ ] Start the service with the test indexer 

```bash
cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --manifest packages/fuel-indexer-tests/components/indices/fuel-indexer-test/fuel_indexer_test.yaml --run-migrations
```
- [ ] Trigger some data `curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/block`
- [ ] Open your playground `http://localhost:29987/api/playground/fuel_indexer_test/index1`
- [ ] Make the following query:

```graphql
query {
  usesnotableentity {
    id
    name
    no_table
  }
}
```
- [ ] Should see your type come back as JSON
```json
{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "name": "hello world",
      "no_table": {
        "name": "norelation",
        "size": 1
      }
    }
  ]
}
```
- Note that the item `NoRelationEntity` already comes back as an object straight from the DB, so no further deserialization is needed

### Changelog

- enhancement: add support for a `@norelation` directive that does not create SQL tables for entities

title: Add forc index command to display indexer metadata
body:
### Description

This PR adds a new `forc index` command: `status`. 

1. `fuel-indexer` without authentication enabled returns all indexers:

```
cargo run --release -p forc-index -- status
```
```
┌─ abc
|  └─ another_another_indexer
|     • id: 8
|     • created_at: 2023-05-19 11:19:20.317939 UTC
|     • pubkey: None
|
├─ another_namespace
|  ├─ hello_indexer
|  |  • id: 3
|  |  • created_at: 2023-05-19 10:29:22.521189 UTC
|  |  • pubkey: None
|  └─ another_indexer
|     • id: 6
|     • created_at: 2023-05-19 10:49:19.376889 UTC
|     • pubkey: None
|
├─ foo
|  └─ some_indexer
|     • id: 9
|     • created_at: 2023-05-22 12:27:20.699031 UTC
|     • pubkey: Some("d39783df2aff5c122d53fa765360e65c3eca9ac7106deaae93d061a180acc5fb5da1f91016c912e2f9dd7cd3e899b58f00b3a8a1f217d969995dec6cf0a3852b")
|
├─ fuel_examples
|  └─ hello_indexer
|     • id: 2
|     • created_at: 2023-05-18 13:51:15.705174 UTC
|     • pubkey: None
|
└─ more_fuel_examples
   ├─ hello_indexer
   |  • id: 4
   |  • created_at: 2023-05-19 10:44:29.822645 UTC
   |  • pubkey: None
   ├─ hello_indexer_2
   |  • id: 5
   |  • created_at: 2023-05-19 10:47:31.166200 UTC
   |  • pubkey: None
   └─ another_another_indexer
      • id: 7
      • created_at: 2023-05-19 11:18:45.130328 UTC
      • pubkey: None
```

2. `fuel-indexer` **with authentication** enabled returns only the indexers whose public key matches:

```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer -- run --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --run-migrations --auth-enabled --auth-strategy JWT
```

```
cargo run --release -p forc-index -- status
```

```
❌ http://127.0.0.1:29987/api/status returned a non-200 response code: 401
```

Unauthorized!

```
cargo run --release -p forc-index -- status --auth $FUEL_JWT_TOKEN
```
```
─ foo
   └─ some_indexer
      • id: 9
      • created_at: 2023-05-22 12:27:20.699031 UTC
      • pubkey: Some("d39783df2aff5c122d53fa765360e65c3eca9ac7106deaae93d061a180acc5fb5da1f91016c912e2f9dd7cd3e899b58f00b3a8a1f217d969995dec6cf0a3852b")
```

### Testing steps

1. Run `fuel-indexer`
2. Add several indexers, preferably in multiple namespaces
3. Run `cargo run -p forc-index -- status`. It should produce an output similar to the one in the description

### Changelog

* Add `/api/status` endpoint to the API server. Returns a JSON list of all registered indexers.
* Add `status` command to `forc index`, which pretty-prints all namespaces and indexers.

title: fix: --embedded-database does not work when using fuel-indexer binary directly
body:
### Description

This PR makes `fuel-indexer start` run an embedded `postgres` database when `--embedded-database` flag is specified.

When `fuel-indexer` exits, the embedded database is shut down. For this purpose, `fuel-indexer` now listens to `SIGHUP/INT/TERM` signals.

### Testing steps

`fuel-indexer`

1. `--embedded-database`
```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --auth-enabled --auth-strategy jwt --jwt-secret $FUEL_JWT_TOKEN --jwt-issuer FuelLabs --postgres-user postgres --postgres-password postgres --postgres-database postgres9 --postgres-port 12345 --embedded-database
```

2. `--embedded-database` and `--local-fuel-node`
```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer --features api-server,fuel-core-lib -- run --run-migrations --postgres-user postgres --postgres-password postgres --postgres-database postgres9 --postgres-port 12345 --embedded-database --local-fuel-node
```
Note: `fuel-core-lib` must be enabled.

3 `--embedded-database` and `--all-features`, `--no-default-features`

```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer --all-features -- run --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --postgres-user postgres --postgres-password postgres --postgres-database postgres9 --postgres-port 12345 --embedded-database
```

```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer --no-default-features -- run --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80 --postgres-user postgres --postgres-password postgres --postgres-database postgres9 --postgres-port 12345 --embedded-database
```

4. `fuel-api-server` `--all-features`, `--no-default-features`

```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer-api-server --all-features -- run --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80
```

```
cargo run -p fuel-indexer-api-server --no-default-features -- run --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80
```

And check it works by visiting:
http://localhost:29987/api/playground/fuel_examples/explorer_indexer

### Changelog

* start an embedded database when `--embedded-database` is specified
* listen for termination signals
* stop the embedded database when a termination signal is received
* cleanup: `forc index start` passes `--embedded-database` flag to `fuel-indexer` instead of calling `forc_postgres::commands::create::exec`
* change how handles are created for various features—no nested cfg's
* vendored `openssl`
    it's a fix for
    ```
    ./fuel-node: error while loading shared libraries: libssl.so.1.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
    ```
    which was suggested here:
    https://github.com/launchbadge/sqlx/issues/473
    "the issue is because procedural macro executed in a slightly different environment"
    I think we're running into the same situation with our Docker build—we build with `cargo chef` image, but run on `ubuntu:22.04`

title: enhancement: integrate `async-graphql` into GraphQL API
body:
### Description

Following the switch from `graphql-parser` to `async-graphql-parser` for our parsing needs, this PR further integrates available features from GraphQL in order to improve the developer experience.

Specifically, it adds the following features:
- #790
- #822 
- #823  

Other GraphQL-idiomatic issues will be addressed in a subsequent PR.

### Testing steps

CI should pass.

#### Manual Testing

The main value add in this PR is introspection support for any user-defined schema in the GraphQL playground. To test this with the block explorer example:
- Ensure the DB is clear and build the required WASM module.
- `cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --manifest examples/block-explorer/explorer-indexer/explorer_indexer.manifest.yaml --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80`
- Open up the playground: `http://localhost:29987/api/playground/fuel_examples/explorer_indexer`
- Open the `Docs` and `Schema` tabs on the side; you should see that there is now information that helps a user to write their queries.
- Begin typing a query; you should see suggestions for usable fields begin to appear. If not, you can press Option+Space (if on a Mac) to bring up the suggestion dropdown, if applicable at the current cursor location.

### Changelog
- Add dynamic schema construction in new `dynamic.rs` module
- Add full auto-generated documentation for GraphQL playground

title: enhancement: add graphql enum support
body:
cc @lostman 

### Description
- PR does a ton of things
  - Fixes type issues in the explorer example 
  - Refactors GraphQL schema codegen and table creation (it was spaghetti code)
  - Adds to concept of "virtual columns" on type IDs
    - Not all types need tables to be created 
    - Not only was this needed for enums but is a precursor for https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/issues/940
  - Cleans up how we're doing imports for the codgen and more important adds comments/explanations
  - Adds new types
    - We now support indexing enum types
      - Enum types have to be persisted into the DB as some type of `FtColumn` so I chose `String`
        - Users can convert this `String` back into its enum on their side if they wish 
  - Adds tests

### Testing steps
- [ ] Tests were added so CI should pass
- [ ] Start a local node `cargo run -p fuel-node --bin fuel-node`
- [ ] Start a local web api `cargo run -p web-api --bin web-api`
- [ ] Start the service using the test indexer 
```bash
cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --manifest packages/fuel-indexer-tests/components/indices/fuel-indexer-test/fuel_indexer_test.yaml --run-migrations
```
- [ ] Trigger the enum event `curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/enum`
- [ ] Open the playground `http://localhost:29987/api/playground/fuel_indexer_test/index1`
- [ ] Query for the indexed enum 

```graphql
query { complexenumentity { id one }}
```
Should return the object with its enum as a String

```json
{
  "data": [
    {
      "id": 1,
      "one": "EnumEntity::One"
    }
  ]
}
```


### Changelog
- Add GraphQL enum support
- Refactor schema and table codegen

title: fix: don't send wasm bytes over service channel
body:
### Description
- PR fixes a bug with `forc index revert`
- Previously `revert` was sending the entire WASM blob over the channel (👎🏽 ) which might have been crashing the channel and closing it
- This PR fixes that by moving the "delete" portion of this to the use-case/handler, and loading the wasm bytes inside the service task (so that only the indexer identifier and namespace are sent over the channel)
- Also renames queries as a part of https://github.com/FuelLabs/fuel-indexer/issues/643
- ⚠️ We won't be able to test for sure that this works til we deploy to beta-3-indexer (after merge to master)
  - But we can still confirm the change locally

### Testing steps
- [ ] Start the service connected to beta-3 `cargo run --bin fuel-indexer -- run --run-migrations --fuel-node-host beta-3.fuel.network --fuel-node-port 80`
- [ ] Deploy the block-explorer example `forc-index deploy --path examples/block-explorer/explorer-indexer --target-dir /Users/rashad/dev/repos/fuel-indexer`
- [ ] Make a change to explorer-indexer/lib.rs. Add a `Logger::info("TESTING REVERT");` to it
- [ ] Redeploy this updated indexer
- [ ] In your database you should see two WASM assets under that indexer ID, and only a single schema and manifest
- [ ] Now call revert `forc-index revert --path examples/block-explorer/explorer-indexer`
- [ ] In the console, you should see the `"TESTING REVERT"` disappear, as the older indexer is reloaded
- [ ] In the database, you should see you still have 1 schema/manifest asset, and now you have 1 wasm asset as well

### Changelog
- fix: don't send wasm bytes over service channel

title: enhancement: convert Scalar types into `Json` and `Blob`

labels.name: breaking
labels.description: This is a change that will break some component of the project once merged to origin/develop

body:
Closes #843

## Changelog
• Adds the macros`json_impl` and `blob_impl` macros for custom Scalar types. 
• Adds unit tests testing the underlying types of our scalar types.
• Changes the type of Blob from an alias to a custom type (see note below about this)
• Updates code elsewhere to integrate the Blob type. 

## NB
I had to make Blob a custom type as apposed to just an alias as it was before. This is because I could not implement a custom `From` trait on an alias of underlying type`Vec<u8>`. But when `Blob is :
```rust
pub struct Blob(pub Vec<u8>);
```
I can implement the From trait. This is because of the orphan rule.

##Testing
This unit test wont run in CI. I don't think we need it to necessarily, but to run the tests cd into 
`packages/fuel-indexer-types/src/` and run `cargo test` this will run the newly created unit tests in the `lib.rs` file

You want to see: 
```
running 8 tests
test tests::test_into_json_blob_int16 ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_id ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_int4 ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_int8 ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_timestamp ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_uint16 ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_uint4 ... ok
test tests::test_into_json_blob_uint8 ... ok
```

title: chore: use `[default-members]` section in `Cargo.toml`
body:
Closes #842.

## Changelog
- Introduce `[default-members]` section
- Change member inclusion to be more idiomatic

## Testing Plan
CI should pass.

## Notes
This change was done to prevent the issue of failed builds when running `cargo build` in the repository root. This structure comes from the [`axum` project](https://github.com/tokio-rs/axum/blob/main/Cargo.toml).

This change also reduces the overall build time of a bare `cargo build`, but makes changes to using the internal testing components. To use internal testing components, a dev should use `cargo run -p [package] --bin [package]`. So in this case of `fuel-node`, one would start it by using `cargo run -p fuel-node --bin fuel-node`.

- [ ] Make a request to metrics `curl http://0.0.0.0:29987/api/metrics`
- [ ] Grep for `postgres_execute_query_calls` in the response and it should have multiple `calls`
  - Currently `curl https://beta-3-indexer.fuel.network/api/metrics` has a `calls` value of `0`

### Changelog
- fix: add postgres package features
